results.title: Horse flickers
results.creator_credit: Bill Stitt Productions, Jim Gruebel, Rhonda Raulston and Bill Stitt
results.brief_description: Non-narrated children’s film in which a series of images of horses comes to life on a barn floor. They are composed of feathers and spangles, newspapers and sleeping bags, human beings and broomsticks and combine imagination, humour, whimsy and art. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Horse feathers
results.brief_description: Groucho, Harpo, Chico and Zeppo star in this anarchic parody of college life. As the President of Huxley College, Groucho is busy keeping his eye on the students, as well as on the curves of vivacious college widow Thelma Todd. She is secretly trying to find the secret football codes to sell to rival college Darwin. “Horse Feathers” includes the riotious classroom war scene and the climatic football game finale where all the rules are broken!

results.title: Horse drawn magic
results.creator_credit: George Johnson, ONF | NFB and Dorothy Todd Henaut
results.brief_description: The Caravan Stage Company is the only horse-drawn open-air theatre in the world. The film shows them on the road and in performance bringing live entertainment to communities where television is often the main diversion. In a montage of short sketches, the film shows the troupe on the road and in performance. Hard work and laughter are basic ingredients of this unconventional lifestyle.

results.title: Horse breaking
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Agrifilm
results.brief_description: Depicts 72 year-old Kel Jeffrey applying his unique and humane method of gaining a horse’s confidence to the point where it will allow a saddle to be placed on its back and a person to ride it.

results.title: Horse
results.creator_credit: Ben Southwell, Justine Kershaw, Oregon Public Broadcasting, Dorling Kindersley Vision, Wildvision and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Eyewitness”.
Horses are an important part of the history of civilisation. Humankind harnessed the energy but never mastered the beast. The fifth fastest land mammal, the horse is the “Marathon” winner of the animal kingdom, renown for its strength and endurance. This program looks at the physionomy of the horse and different horse species such as zebras and donkeys. The horse has occupied a place not only in the history of human beings but in our myths, legends and superstitions. Stunning photography and a behind-the-scenes-look at the making of the program ensure this program is an enriching experience for all ages.

results.title: Hors d'oeuvre = Hors-d'oeuvre
results.creator_credit: Colin Low, Victor Jobin, ONF | NFB, Gerald Potterton, Robert Verrall, Arthur Lipsett, Derek Lamb, Jeffrey Hale and Kaj Pindal
results.brief_description: A collection of short cartoons produced by NFB animators. One-minute clips for government sponsors provide an amusing, fast-paced sampling of animation techniques. Among them are reminders about television programs, traffic safety rules, and the Department of Labour’s admonition, “Why wait for spring? Do it now.”
results.creator_credit_for_label: Colin Low, Victor Jobin, ONF | NFB, Gerald Potterton, Robert Verrall, Arthur Lipsett, Derek Lamb, Jeffrey Hale and Kaj Pindal

results.title: Horror Movie – Skyhooks
results.brief_description: The colourful and quirky music video for Skyhooks’ song ‘Horror Movie’ (1974) helped mark Australian television’s transition from black and white to colour as it was first played on a special, midnight episode of Countdown (1974–87).

constellations_primary.name: Horror movie right there on my TV
constellations_primary.description: The colourful and quirky music video for Skyhooks’ song 'Horror Movie' helped propel them to number one, making it their biggest hit.

constellations_other.name: The secret life of suburbia and music videos
constellations_other.description: Australia's famous streets and suburbs have defined music videos, TV shows and miniseries, providing a unique backdrop to Australian stories and music.

results.description: The colourful and quirky music video for Skyhooks’ song Horror Movie (1974) helped mark Australian television’s transition from black and white to colour as it was first played on a special, midnight episode of Countdown (1974–87). Despite being a political commentary on the state of current affairs at the time, the song became an unintentional Halloween classic after it was included on a compilation album from actress Cassandra Petersen’s character Elvira in 1988.
description_for_label: The colourful and quirky music video for Skyhooks’ song Horror Movie (1974) helped mark Australian television’s transition from black and white to colour as it was first played on a special, midnight episode of Countdown (1974–87). Despite being a political commentary on the state of current affairs at the time, the song became an unintentional Halloween classic after it was included on a compilation album from actress Cassandra Petersen’s character Elvira in 1988.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Australia → 04. Music Video

results.title: Horror Hotel
results.brief_description: Screenwriter George Baxt combines the “Psycho” gimmick of killing the apparent heroine at the beginning of the film with elements of the Salem witches story thrown in for added spine tingling suspense. Professor Driscoll (Christopher Lee) sends Nan (Venetia Stevenson), one of his students, to Whitewood, Massachusetts to research local legends of witchcraft. In the decaying village she is used as a human sacrifice by the witches coven. Nan’s boyfriend and brother go to look for her, and discover an entire village full of zombie-like creatures dressed in monastic habits. The finale is so full of intrigue that you must see this ghoulish epic for yourself.

results.title: Horror express
results.creator_credit: Bernard Gordon, JEF Films and Eugenio Martin
results.brief_description: This hair-raiser is a classic Christopher Lee - Peter Cushing chiller guaranteed to give you goosebumps. It is a real blast of science fiction horror which has as its setting the Trans-Siberian Express. Set in 1906, Lee (an explorer) is returning from China with a mysterious crate containing what he believes are the remains of an apelike creature. This missing link is inhabited by an alien force which can assimilate all the knowledge from people simply by staring at them. The process boils their brains, kills the victims instantly, and makes their eyes bleed and turn white. Late the life force takes over the hapless passengers who appear normal, but are actually zombies possessed by the monsters personality. Lee and Cushing team up to defeat the creature. They saw the tops off the victims heads for brain inspections, only to be horrified by their inexplicable discoveries. The dead passengers, now an army of zombies, march through the train toward the petrified survivors.

results.title: Horowitz in Moscow
results.creator_credit: Robert Dalrymple, Columbia Artists, Camivideo and Brian Large
results.brief_description: This video celebrates the return of Vladimir Horowitz to his home country, the Soviet Union, in 1986 to perform a musical recital at the Moscow Conservatory. It was to be the first important event in a series of cultural exchanges agreed to at the Geneva Summit in 1985. Horowitz calls himself an “ambassador of peace” as he talks to the media, his fans and his family. The biographical documentary captures the emotions of both Horowitz and his adoring fans as he performs some of his favourite compositions by such composers as Mozart, Chopin and Rachmaninov, among others. Interspersed throughout this demanding performance are images of Moscow, the people, streets and cityscape along with insightful interviews with Horowitz as he reminisces about his past. An absorbing and thoughtful documentary featuring some wonderful solo music played by one of the world’s best and highly regarded pianists.
